questions.text: All are autosomal recessive cause of sensorineural hearing loss except
questions.solution:
Examples of Autosomal recessive SNHL:

  • Usher syndrome (types 1, 2, and 3: all associated with blindness, retinitis pigmentosa),
  • Pendred syndrome
  • Jervell and Lange-Nielsen syndrome (one form of the long Q-T syndrome)
  • Alstrom syndrome, type 4 Bartter syndrome, biotinidase deficiency, and DFNB 1-18, 20-23, 26-27, 29-33, 35-40, 42, 44, 46, 48, 49, 53, and 55.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number 3074)

choices.text: Ovaries with polycystic morphology on ultrasound

questions.text: Polycystic ovarian syndrome is a triad of all except
questions.solution: (Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number 2619)

questions.text: Early sign of puberty in male is testicular enlargement, in females it is?
questions.solution:
• In females, the breast bud (thelarche) is usually the first sign of puberty (10-11 year of age), followed by the appearance of pubic hair (pubarche) 6-12 months later.

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 2655)

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is diagnosed with first episode of nephrotic syndrome. Which of the following electrolyte imbalance is not expected in him?
questions.solution:
• The urinalysis reveals 3+ or 4+ proteinuria, and microscopic hematuria is present in 20% of children.
  • A spot urine protein: creatinine ratio should be >0.
  • The serum creatinine value is usually normal. The serum albumin level is <5 g/dL, and serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels are elevated. Serum complement levels are normal.
  • Hyponatremia is a common finding.

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition,, page number. 2521)

choices.text: Serum amino acid and urine organic acids

questions.text: During routine visit of a child, you notice that he is hyperactive, has motor and speech delay and signs of autism. His mother mentions that her brother and her maternal uncle have mental retardation and behaves like preschoolers. Examination shows large ears and the child is nonverbal with hand flapping behavior. Which of the following is the most ideal test to ask for?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this child is Fragile X syndrome.

The features are:

  • Lower IQ, Autism, ADHD, Anxiety
  • Hypothalamic dysfunction like macro-orchidism,
  • Facial features like large cupped ears, elongated face, high arched palate
  • Connective tissue abnormalities like mitral valve prolapse, scoliosis, joint laxity, flat feet
  • Seizures
  • Recurrent otitis media
  • Strabismus

For diagnosis, Southern blot is done to look for CGG repeat sequences.

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number 623)

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl comes with short stature and no secondary sexual characters. Which diagnosis must be considered?
questions.solution:
• Familial short stature and isolated GH deficiency have normal secondary sexual development.
  • Genetic causes of short stature are
    • Turner syndrome
    • Noonan syndrome
    • Prader-Willi syndrome
    • SHOX haploinsufficiency
    • Russel silver syndrome

(Reference: Nelson pediatric symptom-based diagnosis, 20th edition, page number 798)

choices.text: Vaccination can be avoided because they are on penicillin prophylaxis
Episodes of dactylitis should be treated with antibiotics
Gallstones develop before the age of 3 years
Hydroxyurea maintenance therapy reduced the episodes of vaso-occlusive crisis

questions.text: For a child diagnosed with sickle cell anemia, which of the following statements are true?
questions.solution:
• Dactylitis requires palliation with pain medications, such as hydrocodone.
  • In addition to penicillin prophylaxis, routine childhood immunizations, as well as the annual administration of influenza vaccine, are highly recommended. Children with sickle cell anemia develop functional asplenia and also require immunizations to protect against encapsulated organisms including additional pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccinations.
  • Hydroxyurea have found to reduce the episodes of Vaso-occlusive crisis
  • Gallstones develop after 3 years of age

(Reference: Nelson pediatric symptom-based diagnosis, page number 2337)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of cardiopulmonary arrest on pediatric population?
questions.solution:
• Hypoxia and ischemia caused by respiratory distress/failure is the primary cause of cardiac arrest in infants and children.

(Reference. Pediatric Advanced life support manual, AAP, 2022)

choices.text: It is a medical emergency needing respiratory support
Thumb sign is expected on X ray
Barking cough is a rare symptom

questions.text: A 1-year-old child comes to you with high grade fever and respiratory distress for 1 day. On examination, child is sick. On Auscultation, there is stridor. Which of the following statement is true for the probable diagnosis of this child?
questions.solution:
• High grade fever with respiratory distress in a sick looking child and stridor, all points to bacterial epiglottitis. It is a medical emergency.
  • Classic radiographs of a child who has epiglottitis show the thumb Sign.
  • Often, the otherwise healthy child suddenly develops a sore throat and fever. Within a matter of hours, the patient appears toxic, swallowing is difficult, and breathing is labored. Drooling is usually present and the neck is hyperextended in an attempt to maintain the airway. The child may assume the tripod position, sitting upright and leaning forward with the chin up and mouth open while bracing on the arms.
  • A brief period of air hunger with restlessness may be followed by rapidly increasing cyanosis and coma. Stridor is a late finding and suggests near-complete airway obstruction.
  • Antibiotics and respiratory support are priorities in all these patients.

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number 2032)

questions.text: Match the right options, of maternal drug intake in 1st trimester and fetal adverse effects
questions.solution:
• Isotretinoin: Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
  • Alcohol: Congenital cardiac, CNS, limb anomalies; IUGR; developmental delay; attention deficits; autism
  • Aminopterin: Abortion, malformations
  • Amphetamines: Congenital heart disease, IUGR, withdrawal
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor antagonists: Oligohydramnios, IUGR, renal failure, Potter-like syndrome
  • Azathioprine: Abortion
  • Busulfan: Stunted growth; corneal opacities; cleft palate; hypoplasia of ovaries, thyroid, and parathyroids
  • Carbamazepine: Spina bifida, possible neurodevelopmental delay
  • Carbimazole: Scalp defects, choanal atresia, esophageal atresia, developmental delay
  • Carbon monoxide: Cerebral atrophy, microcephaly, seizures
  • Chloroquine: Deafness
  • Chorionic villus sampling: Probably no effect, possibly limb reduction
  • Cigarette smoking: LBW for gestational age
  • Cocaine/crack: Microcephaly, LBW, IUGR, behavioral disturbances
  • Cyclophosphamide: Multiple malformations
  • Danazol: Virilization
  • 17α-Ethinyl testosterone: Masculinization of female fetus
  • Hyperthermia: Spina bifida
  • Infliximab: Possible increased risk of live vaccine associated disease in infant; neutropenia
  • Lithium: Ebstein anomaly, macrosomia
  • Lopinavir-ritonavir: Transient adrenal dysfunction
  • 6-Mercaptopurine: Abortion
  • Methyl mercury: Minamata disease, microcephaly, deafness, blindness, mental retardation
  • Methyltestosterone: Masculinization of female fetus
  • Misoprostol: Arthrogryposis, cranial neuropathies (Mobius syndrome), equinovarus
  • Mycophenolate mofetil: Craniofacial, limb, cardiovascular, CNS anomalies
  • Norethindrone: Masculinization of female fetus
  • Penicillamine: Cutis laxa syndrome
  • Phenytoin: Congenital anomalies, IUGR, neuroblastoma, bleeding (vitamin K deficiency)
  • Polychlorinated biphenyls: Skin discoloration-thickening, desquamation, LBW, acne, developmental delay
  • Prednisone: Oral clefts

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 812)

choices.text: The hip is loose but normally located
The hip is dislocated and irreducible
The hip is dislocated and reducible
The hip is normally located and Dislocatable

questions.text: On newborn examination of hip, it is concluded that Ortolani test is positive. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
• When the test is positive, the femoral head will slip into the socket with a delicate clunk that is palpable but usually not audible. It should be a gentle, non-forced maneuver.
  • It is a reverse of Barlow's test.

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number. 3275)

questions.text: The most common cause of lower GI obstruction in a neonate is?
questions.solution:
• Hirschsprung disease, or congenital a ganglionic mega colon, is a developmental disorder (neurocristopathy) of the enteric nervous system, characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexus.
  • It is the most common cause of lower intestinal obstruction in neonates, with an overall incidence of 1 in 5,000 live births.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 1809)

questions.text: A 6-year-old child has complaint of nasal congestion and chronic rhinorrhea. She continuously keeps cleaning her throat due to post nasal drip. She remains drowsy throughout the day and her snoring has increased. On examination, there is clear rhinorrhea. Which of the following examination finding does not support her diagnosis of allergic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Clinical features of Allergic rhinitis:

  • Older children blow their noses, but younger children tend to sniff and snort. Nasal itching brings on grimacing, twitching, and picking of the nose that may result in epistaxis.
  • Allergic salute, an upward rubbing of the nose with an open palm or extended index finger. This maneuver relieves itching and briefly unblocks the nasal airway. It also gives rise to the nasal crease, a horizontal skin fold over the bridge of the nose.
  • Typical complaints include intermittent nasal congestion, itching, sneezing, clear rhinorrhea, and conjunctival irritation.
  • The patients may lose their sense of smell and taste. Some experience headaches, wheezing, and coughing. Nasal congestion is often more severe at night, causing mouth breathing and snoring, interfering with sleep, and arousing irritability.
  • Signs on physical exam include abnormalities of facial development, dental malocclusion, and the 'allergic gape' or continuous open mouth breathing, chapped lips, 'allergic shiners' (dark circles under the eyes), and the transverse nasal crease.
  • Conjunctival edema, itching, tearing, and hyperemia are frequent findings. A nasal exam performed with a source of light and a speculum may reveal clear nasal secretions; edematous, boggy, and bluish mucus membranes with little or no erythema; and swollen turbinates that may block the nasal airway.
  • Thick, purulent nasal secretions indicate the presence of infection.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number 1089)

questions.text: You attend a neonatal delivery call of a mother who never had any antenatal visits. On routine care, you notice that the nasogastric tube is not passing nasally but passes orally. There are low set ears and some defect in the genitals. The combination of these abnormalities all in which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The baby in the question has, Choanal atresia, ear anomaly and genital anomaly. These fall in CHARGE syndrome.
  • CHARGE syndrome is Coloboma of eye, Heart anomaly, choanal Atresia, mental Retardation, Genital anomaly, Ear anomaly.
  • VATER syndrome is Vertebral defects, imperforate Anus, Tracheo-Esophageal fistula, Renal dysplasia

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number 833)

choices.text: Widened metaphyseal ends of weight bearing joints
Thickened white line at the metaphysis
Loss of sharp border in metaphyseal edges

questions.text: Which of the following is characteristically a feature in X ray plate in a child with Scurvy?
questions.solution:
• The typical radiographic changes occur at the distal ends of the long bones and are particularly common at the knees. The shafts of the long bones have a ground-glass appearance because of trabecular atrophy. The cortex is thin and dense, giving the appearance of pencil outlining of the diaphysis and epiphysis.
  • The white line of Frankel, an irregular but thickened white line at the metaphysis, represents the zone of well-calcified cartilage.
  • The epiphyseal centers of ossification also have a ground-glass appearance and are surrounded by a sclerotic ring.
  • The more specific but late radiologic feature of scurvy is a zone of rarefaction under the white line at the metaphysis. This zone of rarefaction (Trummerfeld zone), a linear break in the bone that is proximal and parallel to the white line, represents area of debris of broken-down bone trabeculae and connective tissue.
  • A Pelkan spur is a lateral prolongation of the white line and may be present at cortical ends. Epiphyseal separation can occur along the line of destruction, with either linear displacement or compression of the epiphysis against the shaft.
  • Subperiosteal hemorrhages are not visible using plain radiographs during the active phase of scurvy. However, during healing the elevated periosteum becomes calcified and radiopaque, sometimes giving a dumbbell or club shape to the affected bone.

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number 333)

choices.text: It is common after the 3rd dose of oral polio
It occurs with oral polio vaccine and not injectable polio
It is more likely if it is co-administered with multiple parenteral injections
It is more likely to occur if co-administered with rotavirus vaccine

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Vaccine associated paralytic polio (VAPP)?
questions.solution:
• IPV carries no risk of VAPP.
  • It is common after 1st dose of OPV
  • It has no association with co-administration of other vaccines.

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 1557)

questions.text: A 2-year-old child has been diagnosed with Measles. All family members are unvaccinated to measles. They are concerned about the chances of contracting the illness in the family members. What is the secondary attack rate of measles?
questions.solution: (Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 1580)

questions.text: Which candida infection in newborns are contracted from caregivers' hands?
questions.solution:
• They are most common strains causing hospital acquired candida infections.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number 3220)

questions.text: A 3 year old child comes in the OPD with complaint of fever and coughing for 6 days. On examination, child is irritable, fever 103F, mild neck rigidity, and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. He has macular rashes as shown, bilateral conjunctival congestion with secretion, dry chapped lips and strawberry tongue. What I the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child in the case is falling into criteria for diagnosis of Kawasaki disease as below

EPIDEMIOLOGIC CASE DEFINITION (CLASSIC CLINICAL CRITERIA)

  • Fever persisting at least 5 days
  • Presence of at least 4 principal features:
    • Changes in extremities:
      • Acute: Erythema of palms, soles; edema of hands, feet
      • Subacute: Periungual peeling of fingers, toes in weeks 2 and 3
    • Polymorphous exanthem
    • Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate
    • Changes in lips and oral cavity: erythema, lip cracking, strawberry tongue, diffuse injection of oral and pharyngeal mucosa
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy (>5 cm diameter), usually unilateral
  • Exclusion of other diseases with similar findings

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number 1210)

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with a low fever and a modestly itchy skin rash. One week before a flu-like syndrome with fever, headache, myalgia, and sore throat occurred. He was treated with oral paracetamol 250 mg twice a day. He was vaccinated and had always been in good health prior to the rash. On physical examination the exanthema consisted of erythematous maculo-papules started on the trunk and the limb roots, with an appearance of goose bumps of the skin. Hyperemic and hypertrophic tonsils and modest hepatomegaly were also present. The day after the exanthema spread to the face and to the latero-cervical and retro-auricular regions. After two days the lesions took on a purpuric color and the so-called 'yellow hand sign' appeared. By exerting a light hand pressure on the abdomen, where the exanthema was clear, a fleeting shape of the hand with a sub-jaundiced color was evident. This was an expression of hepatic suffering and a consequent increase in bilirubinemia. Based on the case description and the photographs which is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Measles and rubella could be excluded not only for the different appearance but mainly because the child had received specific vaccines.
  • In scarlet fever, the rash begins after one to five days from a feverish onset and starts at the limb roots, then spreads over the entire body surface, typically sparing the perioral region (the Filatov mask). The tongue is white and patinated with red margins, then peels and takes on a raspberry appearance.
  • In our case, the clinical picture was very different due to the onset of the exanthema (although identical in morphology and distribution) at the same time as the onset of fever. Additionally, the fever was low fever, there were good general conditions and an absence of lymphadenomegaly and tonsillar exudate.
  • Typically, the exanthema involves the face with an intense red colour. It is mainly on the cheeks with a 'slapped cheek' appearance and spares the perioral area that remains pale.
  • Subsequently, the erythema spreads to the trunk and limbs. Maculo-papular lesions are often itchy and tend to merge into larger patches (megalo-erythema), pale in the center creating a reticulated or cockade appearance.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 1570)

questions.text: Stage XN of vitamin A deficiency refers to
questions.solution: (Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number 319)

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents with ventricular tachycardia, severe ventricular dysfunction, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis. The patient is cardioverted into ventricular fibrillation which degenerates into asystole. Which of the following is the most appropriate indication to start IV epinephrine in this patient?
questions.solution:
• If defibrillation is ineffective or fibrillation recurs, amiodarone or lidocaine may be given intravenously and defibrillation repeated. If asystole is seen, epinephrine must be given.

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition,, page number 2257)

questions.text: 6-year-old child comes to clinic for regular follow-up. Family is strict vegan. Child used to consume outside food frequently. He eats plenty of dark green vegetables and iron-fortified grains. This child is at risk of developing which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
• Vitamin B12 deficiency because of inadequate dietary intake occurs primarily in persons consuming strict vegetarian or vegan diets.

(Reference, Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number 328)

choices.text: More than 99% have bilateral descended testes at the age of 1
Impaired sperm production is not a concern if neither testes descends
It has no association with inguinal hernia
Microphallus is a common finding in these children

questions.text: You examine a full-term newborn at birth. The testes are not palpable in scrotum. On testes is high up in the right inguinal canal and cannot be gently manipulated into anatomically correct position. Th other testes is not palpable but can be traced in the abdomen after consulting a urologist and doing an ultrasound. Which of the following statements about this condition of the child is true?
questions.solution:
• An indirect inguinal hernia usually accompanies a congenital undescended testis but rarely is symptomatic.
  • The consequences of cryptorchidism include poor testicular growth, infertility, testicular malignancy, associated hernia, torsion of the cryptorchid testis, and the possible psychologic effects of an empty scrotum.
  • More than 99% have bilateral descended testes at the age of 1

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number. 2593)

questions.text: A woman with seizure disorder under medical management wants to conceive a child. Her risk of having a neural tube defect is greatest if her gestational medical regimen includes which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
• Carbamazepine: Spina bifida, possible neurodevelopmental delay

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 812)

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant comes with history of abnormal movements. The episode has recurrent rhythmic flexor-extensor spasms that repeat about 30 times before subsiding. The EEG shows hypsarrhythmia and a Woods lamp exam is positive for several flat hypopigmented macules scattered over the skin surface. This child's infantile spasms are most likely as a result of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
• The most common neurologic manifestations of TSC consist of epilepsy, cognitive impairment, and autism spectrum disorders. TSC may present during infancy with infantile spasms and a hypsarrhythmic electroencephalogram pattern.
  • More than 90% of patients show the typical hypomelanotic macules that have been likened to an ash leaf on the trunk and extremities. Visualization of the hypomelanotic macule is enhanced by the use of a Wood ultraviolet lamp.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number 2877)

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl comes to you with fever and abdominal pain. She met with an accident yesterday while riding a bicycle. Her mother noticed that the abdomen is distended since the morning on the right side. Also, she passed red urine since the morning. She has hypertension on examination and tender distended abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Considering the acute history of fever and abdominal pain, with onset after the accident, rules out the infective cause.
  • As there is hypertension and hematuria, renal trauma is the most likely diagnosis in the above scenario.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 550)

questions.text: A 2-year-old, 14kg boy comes to you with watery diarrhea for last 12 hours. Skin pinch is delayed and child is lethargic. He has passed urine before 6 hours. After initial bolus of 280ml given twice, hydration status is improved, HR stabilizes and urine is passed. For the next 24 hours which maintenance fluid must be given and at what rate?
questions.solution:
• The child has severe dehydration, indicated by lethargy.
  • Management of Severe dehydration:
    • Restore intravascular volume: Normal saline: 20 mL/kg over 20 min, Repeat as needed
    • Calculate 24-hr fluid needs: maintenance + deficit volume
    • Subtract isotonic fluid already administered from 24 hr fluid needs
    • Administer remaining volume over 24 hr using 5% dextrose NS + 20 mEq/L KCl
    • Replace ongoing losses as they occur
  • For severe dehydration in this child, fluid deficit= weight x 10% x 10= 1400ml

Maintenance fluid according to Holiday Segar formula= 1200ml

Total fluid needed in 24 hours= 2600ml

Initial fluid bolus given= 560ml

Remaining fluid to be given over next 24 hours= 2600-560ml=2040ml= 85ml/hr.

(Reference. nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number 389)

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy comes with growth failure and vague abdominal pain. Abdomen is distended on examination. There is no perianal disease, abdominal mass, or tenderness. The next set of investigations to be done are
questions.solution:
• All the options are needed as a part of workup for FTT with abdominal pain. During the approach we must first rule out celiac disease by doing Celiac panel (incl TTG) and then move on to radiological evaluation.

(Reference: nelson pediatric symptom-based diagnosis, page number. 157)

choices.text: Mid-systolic click followed by a murmur
Nonspecific ejection murmur at the base of heart

questions.text: A 14-year-old, with anorexia nervosa has fallen to 80% of her ideal body weight for height and gender. She has not menstruated in 9 months. She has postural hypotension and bradycardia. Which of the following murmurs is most likely to be present on this patients cardiac examination?
questions.solution:
• The incidence of mitral valve prolapse increases in anorexia nervosa. Cardiac evaluation shows a mid-systolic click followed by a murmur of mitral valve regurgitation.

(Reference: nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number 164)

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with sudden onset petechia and ecchymoses. Otherwise, child is well and stable. No splenomegaly or lymphadenopathy. Cbc shows normal WBC counts but platelet count is 12000/mm3. There are large platelets on peripheral smear. No premature white cells. Child had a brief viral illness before 2 weeks. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A well appearing child with no fever, rules out sepsis.
  • There is no splenomegaly, and WBC counts are normal, hypersplenism ruled out.
  • Petechia in an otherwise well child and large platelets in peripheral smear indicated ITP. Also there is a history of a viral illness a couple of weeks back which has precipitated the disease. Splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, bone pain, and pallor are rare.

(Reference: nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 2404)

questions.text: A 7- day -old infant has copious purulent discharge from both eyes. The 17-year -old mother currently complains of a yellowish vaginal discharge. The only medications received by the infant were vitamin K and topical erythromycin prophylaxis following delivery. Giemsa stain of a conjunctival scraping reveals intracytoplasmic inclusions. After obtaining appropriate diagnostic studies, the BEST management includes treatment with
questions.solution:
• Maternal yellowish vaginal discharge and the baby having conjunctivitis, have two common organisms as a cause- Chlamydia and Gonococcus.
  • Presence of intracytoplasmic inclusions in Giemsa stain is specific for Chlamydia.
  • Neonatal conjunctivitis secondary to chlamydial infections is treated with oral erythromycin (50 mg/kg/24 hr in 4 divided doses) for 2 wk. This cures conjunctivitis and may prevent subsequent chlamydial pneumonia.

(Reference. nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number 3038)

questions.text: All the following are features in Kawasaki syndrome except
questions.solution:
• Cervical NOT axillary LN, most commonly unilateral, tender. At least one node >1.5cm.

CLASSIC CRITERIA FOR KAWASAKI SYNDROME

  • Fever persisting at least 5 days
  • Presence of at least 4 principal features:
    • Changes in extremities:
      • Acute: Erythema of palms, soles; edema of hands, feet
      • Subacute: Periungual peeling of fingers, toes in weeks 2 and 3
    • Polymorphous exanthem
    • Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate
    • Changes in lips and oral cavity: erythema, lip cracking, strawberry tongue, diffuse injection of oral and pharyngeal mucosa
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy (>5 cm diameter), usually unilateral
  • Exclusion of other diseases with similar findings

(Reference. nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 1210)

questions.text: A child with chronic renal failure is expected to develop all the following Except:
questions.solution:
Manifestations of Chronic kidney disease:

  • Accumulation of nitrogenous waste
  • Acidosis
  • Sodium retention
  • Sodium wasting
  • Urinary concentrating defect
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Renal osteodystrophy
  • Growth retardation
  • Anemia
  • Bleeding tendency
  • CNS symptoms like fatigue, poor concentration, headache, drowsiness, memory loss, seizures, peripheral neuropathy
  • GI symptoms like feeding intolerance, abdominal pain
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Pericarditis, cardiomyopathy
  • Glucose intolerance

(Reference. nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number. 2544)

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with tachypnea, poor perfusion, gallop rhythm, diminished pulses, and hepatomegaly. Arterial blood gas shows metabolic acidosis. Echocardiography reveals critical aortic stenosis. Of the following, the intervention MOST likely to stabilize the infant's condition is:
questions.solution:
• Prostaglandin E1 is crucial for keeping the patent ductus arteriosus in critical congenital heart disease for the survival and palliation of particularly prematurely born babies until a surgical intervention is available.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number n. 2204)

questions.text: While at school, a 6-year-old boy is noted by his teacher to experience 10- to 20-second lapses in consciousness, sometimes with clonic movements of the face. His parents have not noticed this behavior at home. Electroencephalography shows 3 per second generalized spike and wave discharges. The MOST appropriate therapy for this boy is:
questions.solution:
• The child in the question has absence seizures.
  • Absence seizures are characterized by a brief loss and return of consciousness, generally not followed by a period of lethargy (i.e., without a notable postictal state).
  • Treatment of patients with absence seizures only is mainly with valproic acid or ethosuximide, which are of equal efficacy controlling absences in around 75% of patients.

(Reference. Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number 2835)

questions.text: Shakir tape is used for
questions.solution:
Used for measurement of midarm circumference in diagnosis and follow-up of PEM children.

(Reference. Ghai's essential of pediatrics, 8th edition, page number. 97)

questions.text: The commonest cause of secondary nocturnal enuresis in children is
questions.solution:
• Psychological stress or traumatic experience are the commonest cause of secondary enuresis.
  • UTI and constipation are other common cause.
  • DM, DI, spina bifida and stress incontinence are rarer causes.

(Reference. Ghai's essential of pediatrics, 8th edition., page number 504)

questions.text: An average increase in the length of a full term child in 1st year of life is
questions.solution: (Reference. Ghai's essential of pediatrics, 8th edition, page number 13)

questions.text: Parents of a 2-year-old child visits you with complaint of child not eating sufficient. Child is active and weight & height is at 50th centile. There is no recent weight loss. On examination child is healthy. What must be advised for this child
questions.solution:
• The child is growing well and upto the mark. It rules out any acute event like sepsis.
  • Also, there are no signs of deficiency, hence no point of giving multivitamins.
  • Forceful eating creates a psychological stress on the child and affects the mental health, hence not advised.
  • Not eating is a subjective finding. If the child is growing well and development is upto the mark, no active intervention is needed.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition., page number. 1759)

questions.text: Two carpal bones are radiologically seen in the wrist X-ray of most of the children by the end of
questions.solution: (Reference: Nelson pediatrics symptom-based diagnosis, page number. 791)

questions.text: An infant sit with minimal support, attempts to attain a toy beyond reach, rolls over from supine to prone position and does not have pincer grasp is at a development of
questions.solution:
• Sit with support: 6 months
  • Roll over from supine to prone: 5 months
  • Reach for toy: 4 months
  • Pincer grasp: 9 months

Hence, best answer is 6 months

(Reference:. Ghai's essential of pediatrics, 8th edition, page number 50)

questions.text: Excess of vitamin K in a new born causes
questions.solution:
• Symptoms of hypervitaminosis K are jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, hemolytic anemia, and kernicterus in infants.

(Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number. 799)

questions.text: Which one of the following contains least fat content in the milk
questions.solution: (Reference: Nutrition and child development, KE Elizabeth, 5th edition, page number 719)

questions.text: Richa, a 6 years old girl is seen at the school clinic for growth and development monitoring. Which of the following is characterized the rate of growth during this period?
questions.solution:
• During the Preschooler stage growth is very minimal. Weight gain is only 2kgs per year and Height is 6-8cm per year.
  • Most rapid growth and development- Infancy
  • Slow growth- Toddler hood and Preschooler
  • Slower growth- School age
  • Rapid growth- Adolescence

(Reference: Nutrition and child development, KE Elizabeth, 5th edition)

choices.text: Can be estimated by determination of maternal serum alpha -fetoprotein in all future pregnancies
Is increased for Down syndrome, but not for any other chromosomal abnormality
Is no greater than that of any other woman her age
Is not increased until she reaches the age of 35

questions.text: A female infant born to a 24- year- old woman has been diagnosed clinically as having Down syndrome. The mother is concerned about her risk of having another child who has a chromosomal abnormality. The statement that you are MOST likely to include in your discussion is that her risk
questions.solution:
• Maternal serum AFP is commonly used for screening of Downs syndrome in 1st and 2nd
  • Chromosome analysis is indicated in every person suspected of having Down syndrome. If a translocation is identified, parental chromosome studies must be performed to determine whether one of the parents is a translocation carrier, which carries a high recurrence risk for having another affected child. That parent might also have other family members at risk. Translocation (21;21) carriers have a 100% recurrence risk for a chromosomally abnormal child, and other Robertsonian translocations, such as t (14;21), have a 5-7% recurrence risk when transmitted by females. Hence, option b is incorrect.
  • The risk of having a child with Down syndrome is 1/1,300 for a 25-year-old woman; at age 35, the risk increases to 1/365. At age 45, the risk of a having a child with Down syndrome increases to 1/30. Hence before 35 years, mother is not risk-free to Dow's child.
  • If a patient has had a trisomy 21 pregnancy in the past, the risk of recurrence in a subsequent pregnancy increases to approximately 1 percent above the baseline risk determined by maternal age. Hence, option c is incorrect.

(Reference: nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number. 613)

choices.text: Bilateral paralysis of the vocal cords

questions.text: You are evaluating a 1- month- old boy who has had inspiratory stridor since birth. The stridor is associated with retractions when the infant becomes agitated. Physical examination reveals a weight of 3.4 kg (10th percentile), no expiratory stridor, and weak cry. Of the following, the MOST likely cause of the stridor in this infant is
questions.solution:
• Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital laryngeal anomaly and the most common cause of stridor in infants and children. Sixty percent of congenital laryngeal anomalies in children with stridor are due to laryngomalacia.
  • Stridor is inspiratory, low-pitched, and exacerbated by any exertion: crying, agitation, or feeding. The stridor is caused, in part, by decreased laryngeal tone leading to supraglottic collapse during inspiration.

(Reference. nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number 2036)

questions.text: A male infant is born at an estimated gestational age of 34 weeks. His measurements at birth are: weight- 1, 200 g (<10th percentile); length- 40 cm (10th percentile); and head circumference, 31.5 cm (50th percentile). Of the following, the MOST likely explanation for the growth pattern of this infant is
questions.solution:
• The child in the question has asymmetrical growth retardation. Weight and length are affected with head spared (head sparing effect).
  • Causes of asymmetrical IUGR are the ones causing placental insufficiency. This includes PIH, maternal medical diseases.
  • Gestational diabetes causes macrosomia.
  • Chromosomal abnormality and congenital viral infection cause symmetrical IUGR.

(Reference. Ghai's essential of pediatrics, 8th edition,page number 155)

choices.text: Abdominal radiography to look for the 'double- bubble' sign
Insertion of a rectal tube for decompression
Placement of a nasogastric tube and initiation of intravenous fluid therapy
Upper gastrointestinal radiographic series to look for malrotation of the small bowel

questions.text: A 1- day -old infant develops bilious vomiting and no gastric distension. She has been afebrile and has been passing meconium- laden stools. Of the following, the most appropriate INITIAL step in the management of this infant is
questions.solution:
• The hallmark of duodenal obstruction is bilious vomiting without abdominal distention, which is usually noted on the 1st day of life. The diagnosis is suggested by the presence of a 'double-bubble' sign on a plain abdominal radiograph.
  • Contrast studies are generally not necessary and may be associated with aspiration.
  • The initial treatment of infants with duodenal atresia includes nasogastric or orogastric decompression and intravenous fluid replacement.

(Reference. nelson textbook of pediatrics, 20th edition, page number. 1801)

choices.text: Undocumented void in the delivery room

questions.text: A vigorous, normal -appearing term male newborn has not voided by 18 hours after delivery. Perinatal history is negative for maternal illness or medications. Amniotic fluid volume was reportedly normal, and the delivery was uneventful, with Apgar scores of 6 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Of the following, the MOST likely reason why this 18- hour- old infant has not voided is
questions.solution:
• After birth, most babies void on the first day but all babies must pass urine in first 48 hours. In most cases of alleged non-passage of urine, the baby actually passed urine in the delivery room which has been overlooked.

(Reference: Care of newborn, Meharban Singh, 8th edition, Page number. 158)
